p: India has witnessed in the recent past large outbreaks of emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases that have ravaged the resource-limited country (Robert 1959; David 1986; Suri and Sen 2011; Dikid et al. 2013). After successfully containing deadly outbreaks of Nipah virus and other high-threat pathogens, and building on the success in eliminating polio, India is now readying itself to address the threat of an influenza pandemic. The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) and WHO jointly hosted a gathering of leading experts from the fields of public health, virology, epidemiology, surveillance, clinical medicine, One Health, disaster management, behavioural science, risk communication and the defence sector to identify and address challenges that India would face during an influenza pandemic (WHO Report 2014; Swetha et al. 2019).
